awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Biosocial Consequences of Food Insecurity Among Chronic Disease Patients
awd_abstract_narration:
Amid a rise in chronic diseases, there is a pressing need to understand how social and economic inequalities impact disease management. As a fundamental human need, food provides one valuable window into these dynamics. The relationship between food insecurity and diet-related chronic disease is well-documented, yet the pathways that underlie this relationship remain poorly understood. This doctoral dissertation project aims to provide greater clarity on this relationship by exploring food as a vehicle of both nutritional and social significance in the everyday lives of individuals managing diet-related chronic disease. In addition to providing scientific training for a graduate student, this project involves cooperative institutional partnerships, which broaden scientific participation and allow for insights and data to be directly shared with those who shape clinical practice. The findings will be disseminated widely to academic and non-academic audiences, health and nutrition practitioners, and community organizations, with important implications for improving clinical practice, nutrition counseling, and food security efforts. 

Specifically, this research applies a biosocial theoretical lens to investigate 1) healthcare providers’ perceptions and practices related to food insecurity and diet; 2) meanings patients attribute to the lived experience of food insecurity; 3) patients' food access, preferences, and choices; and 4) the effects of these factors on patients’ health outcomes. A combination of qualitative and quantitative methods, including interviews with providers and patients, structured surveys, and biological measurements (height, weight, blood pressure, cholesterol, and glycated hemoglobin), will be used to achieve these research aims. The study will be conducted in collaboration with a rural community health clinic. This combination of theoretical approaches and methods from nutrition and the social sciences provides a novel approach to the examination of food insecurity and chronic disease.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Food insecurity—a lack of physical, social, and economic access to sufficient, safe, and nutritious food that meets dietary needs and food preferences for an active and healthy life—affects approximately one in ten adults in the United States and disproportionately affects those who reside in the South. This research sought to explore how food insecurity becomes embodied in adverse cardiometabolic health outcomes among those residing in this region. 

 The primary site of this research was Tift County, Georgia—a rural county located in South Georgia characterized by an evident dedication to agriculture evident in a four-year agriculture college, a campus of the University of Georgia, and a United States Department of Agriculture research campus. In stark contrast to this commitment to agricultural production, Tift County has higher rates of food insecurity than other parts of the state, with current county-level estimates between 17-20% of individuals impacted. A devotion to agriculture, a tourist-driven food environment, expanding healthcare system, and increasing investment on behalf of food-based nonprofit agencies made Tift County a fruitful site in which to explore the intersections of food insecurity and well-being. 

This research employed both qualitative and quantitative methods, including semi-structured interviews with individuals living with chronic conditions, health providers who attend to patients with chronic conditions, and nonclinical hospital staff, as well as informal interviews and observations among staff from food-related and health-related non-governmental organizations and community organizers working in South Georgia. In addition, survey and biometric data were collected in partnership with a local community health clinic to examine the prevalence of food insecurity, explore its associations with cardiometabolic outcomes, and test whether dietary factors or perceived stress mediated an observed relationship between food insecurity and adverse health.

There were several key findings from this research: First, healthcare providers in South GA view food insecurity and comorbidity as prevalent issues among patients. Many strive to perform buffering activities to alleviate adversity. However, there are constraints on this expansive form of care work. Additionally, amid growing calls for food security screening, many providers expressed reluctance or hesitation to discuss food insecurity for fear that it may promote shame, stigma, or embarrassment. Second, individuals living with chronic conditions enacted various coping strategies to buffer and manage insecurity. Importantly, their experiences of insecurity and deprivation did not deter or halt sociality; instead, many individuals living with food insecurity relied upon food sharing and communal meals to buffer precarity and solidify social relationships. Individuals often interwove a patchwork of federal, state, institutional, and individual coping strategies to form a safety net. Finally, we found that individuals with chronic conditions experienced biological and social consequences related to food insecurity. Data from a community health clinic sample revealed a high prevalence of food insecurity, psychosocial stress, obesity, and hypertension. Survey and biometric data suggest that food insecurity is associated with perceived stress and dietary quality and that stress may moderate the effect of insecurity on certain health markers. As part of this work, we generated new knowledge about the experience of food insecurity and health in the American South, particularly the social and communal value people place on food.

This study is one of few empirically examining the psychosocial and nutritional pathways thought to relate food insecurity to health outcomes. This research adds to an interdisciplinary scholarship at the intersection of critical medical anthropology, human biology, and nutrition by positioning clinical sites as vital avenues of inquiry into the investigation and alleviation of health disparities, examining the biological and sociocultural contributions to health disparities, and crafting a more engaged social science agenda to support investments at the intersection of food and nutrition security and human well-being. This research also contributed to training a first-generation female graduate student in the United States. It provided capacity-building for a health system, local nonprofit organizations, and community members invested in alleviating social determinants in a rural region.  

Most importantly, this research underscores that food insecurity adversely affects cardiometabolic and mental health as part of broader experiences of poverty, uncertainty, and inequality in the American South. Our research found that while many healthcare providers strive to perform buffering activities to alleviate adversity, there are constraints on this expansive form of care work. Moreover, amid calls and mandates for food security screening, health systems may face challenges to implementation. Gaps between healthcare and social work also affect provider-patient interactions and patients’ experiences with insecurity. Our research also found that while food insecurity is associated with higher perceived stress and lower dietary quality, perceptions of psychosocial stress moderate the relationship between food insecurity and adverse health (in this case, hypertension). Our work suggests that interventions designed to alleviate food insecurity, particularly those partnered with healthcare organizations, must account for the social dimensions of food and nutrition and should be embedded within broader poverty-reduction efforts.
